page.lettertext:
fol.219r
May it please yo
r
good L. Because I doe assure my self that the
occurrences of the Campe are advertised from those,
at are actors
there in place, I showld but trouble yo
r
L. w
t
speeches that
goe heere w
ch
are oftentimes uncertaine. But yet to signifie
in generall w
at
is written from thens. The batterie began the 3
of this moneth, and were bestowed to the number of 5000
shotte but all in a manner cast away: partly by reason of
the hight of the Counterscarffe, and partly through the strenght
of the ramparts of the towne, w
ch
were both very large and
firnely compact of tough and solide mater. They failed also
in their sapping, by meanes of stony places, that stopped their
passage. Howebite they attempt it againe in an other quarter
and have devised other stratagemes: w
ch
will cost many lives
howsoever they take effect: And if nothing will prevaile to
the winning of the place, it is commonly supposed that wee
shall then have an ende of this sommers exploites: w
ch
will
offer an opportunitie to have her
Ma
ties
last demaunde solicited
a freshe, if the
y
present estate of the
King
doe require it
wherein yo
r
L. will vouchesafe to certifie her pleasure. I
neede not signifie unto yow the grievous complaint of the
marchantes of
Zeland,
upon the taking of their shippe,
at
came newly out of
Spaine:
whereof the
states
of that Pro-
vince have written to her Ma
tie
. But yet the copie of their
complaint, because it is indited in cholericke tearmes, and
w
t
shewe of great dislike of the courses that are taken in
their causes in England, and for that I stand in some
doubt, it is not otherwise sent yo
r
L. I have inclosed in
this letter, together w
t
a copie of the mariners depositions
Moreoever the states of Zeland have written letters hither
to request the
General states
, to joine w
t
them in this
suite, for the intreating of her Hig
nes
to cause a present
resititution of the goods of the foresaide marchantes: w
ch
hath bin imparted all unto me, by certaine deputies of the
fol.219v
To my L.
[Tresurer]
9 June 1592
states, that were appointed this morning, to repaire unto [me]
about it, and to require my assistaunce. Who have told [me]
in w
at
[tune] they finde the marchaunt
of these contreis an[d]
how greatly it doth behoove in regard that they are many a[.]
are the chiefest contributors to the charges of these warrres, [.]
prevent in good time,
at there come no mischief of this mate[r]
between the Englishe and Zeland marchants, or other daung[e]
rows alteration in the affaires of this state. I omitted no
endevo
r
to persuade them w
t
good speeches,
at her Ma
tie
would
give order for the hearing of their cause w
t
equitie and favo[r]
and I moved them the while to seeke to moderate, as they
might, the passionat proceeding of the marchants that com[-]
plained: w
ch
I thought very needfull to advertise w
t
speede.
Hage. June 9 1592.
